Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds part of the research activity of Professor Savvas Koushiappas at Brown University. The main goal of this award is to unite theoretical studies of the physics of dark matter with current and future experimental efforts. The experimentally motivated theoretical projects use observations of high energy photons and other energetic particles such as positrons and neutrinos (into which dark matter might decay or annihilate) in order to tackle fundamental questions about the nature of dark matter, the origin of astrophysical backgrounds, the astrophysical effects of cosmology and most importantly the interplay and connections among these different topics. The primary goal is the interpretation of dark matter indirect detection search data in the context of dark matter properties and the implications for accelerator studies. A secondary goal is the understanding and improvement of systematic uncertainties that arise from astrophysical processes and the cosmological context. The outcome of this work will help understand the confidence at which theoretical dark matter interpretations can be ruled out from null searches, and to establish the confidence to which dark matter's physical properties can be measured in future experimental efforts.

Any dark matter experimental technique is ultimately linked to the details of the interplay between particle physics, astrophysics and cosmology. For example direct detection experiments depend on the local density and velocity distribution of dark matter, indirect detection experiments depend on the square of the dark matter density along a line of sight, and each of these techniques depends on the cross section of interactions and the mass of the dark matter particle, both of which are probed in accelerator searches. It is therefore imperative that theoretical interpretations of experimental results in the context of particle physics must take into account this amalgamation of information. This research will bridge the gap between these disciplines, making the connection between astrophysics, cosmology and particle physics possible by understanding the uncertainties and connections between different disciplines. These goals will be achieved by sophisticated theoretical modeling, and new and existing statistical and analysis tools. In addition, the broader impact pertains to the synergy between indirect detection, direct detection and Large Hadron Collider (LHC) searches, thus connecting the laboratory to the sky, a necessary link that must be in place for any convincing dark matter interpretation of any signal. Furthermore, graduate and undergraduate education at the PI's institution will benefit from the exposure to cosmology, particle physics and computing, as well as the development and implementation of new computational and analysis tools. And finally, the proposed outreach activities of the PI will allow the public and students within Providence to engage in science-related activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The composition of the Universe is one of the fundamental questions of physics. We know the universe is made up of electrons and protons (the periodic table of elements) and light. But detailed observations in the last 80 years led to a most interesting fact, that is the universe has an additional component that “feels” gravity but cannot be “seen” with light, this is what we call dark matter.

This award was focused on trying to understand some of the properties of dark matter. More specifically, this research led to five main results regarding dark matter:

1) Set the strongest constraints on the annihilation cross section of the dark matter particle. These results required a very large effort on two areas. First, developing the statistical formalism so that it is optimized in the search of a signal and second, understanding the theoretical systematics that enter in the interpretation of experimental data.  

2) Reticulum II is a newly discovered dwarf galaxy that was found in the first data release of the Dark Energy Survey. Applying the formalism developed for dark matter search (see above) to this dwarf galaxy we found an indication of a small excess in gamma rays (a prediction dark matter interactions in some specific dark matter theories). In addition we showed that if the small excess in energetic photos is due to dark matter then the observed cross section is within the errors of the expected annihilation cross section of a thermal relic, on other words the abundance of dark matter is in agreement with what is observed. 

3) In most theories the present-day dark matter is produced from the decay of a heavier dark matter particle. Typically this takes place very early universe, or it can take place at late times if it produces a dark matter particle with a thermal velocity (whose motivation is to solve a number of outstanding problems in galaxy formation). We derived the effects of generic dark matter decays on the cosmological expansion rate by computing the equation of state of the daughter (present-day dark matter) particle -- the relationship between density and pressure of dark matter. 

4) In a work with colleagues working in particle physics phenomenology we looked at Large Hadron Collider (LHC) constraints on dark matter candidates with a pseudoscalar mediating interaction between the dark matter particle and Standard Model particles. These candidates are interesting because even though they can have weackly interacting properties they can typically evade direct detection. In addition, we investigated signatures of vector-like fermions and placed LHC constraints on several decay channels.

5) The remarkable discovery of gravitational waves by LIGO in 2016 led to a plethora of speculation as to where did the merging pairs of the first event came from. One suggestion that received quite a bit of attention has been primordial black holes, black holes formed at or soon after inflation in the early universe. Using dynamical arguments we showed that primordial black holes cannot be all of dark matter in the universe. We derived this conclusion by computing the time evolution of the phase distribution of stars in a potential well dominated by massive primordial black holes (more massive than stars).

The results of this work (8 publications) were published in peer-review journals ), as well as presented in 22 talks given as seminars, and colloquia in conferences and workshops as well as public talks. In addition it led to the training of a graduate student who completed a Ph.D. degree in physics and is currently employed as a data analyst.
